Irish Rail concedes to campaigners over out-of-order lifts

IRISH RAIL has responded to pressure from campaigners and will replace and upgrade lifts at all Dart and commuter rail stations over the next five years. 

“This is an amazing victory for the disabled community. Their right to access to public transport has finally been recognized” said Bernard Mulvany, co-coordinator with Sean O’Kelly of the Access for All Campaign

On one day in November, Access for All Ireland said there were 11 Dart stations where lifts were out of order. Recently, the campaign had seen that the out-of-service lifts was getting worse at Dart stations.

Today Bernard Mulvany, who is a candidate for People before Profit in Dublin Bay North said:

“This proves that campaigning works. It is the only way to get change. Irish Rail had no regard for accessibility to their trains. They would have got away with it for ever had our campaign not reminded them every day that people were suffering as a result of this”

A tender issued by the company this week outlines plans to install 28 new lifts and upgrade a further 112 lifts across Irish Rail’s network between 2020 and 2024. 

Irish Rail have committed to the following upgrades.28 new heavy-duty, stainless steel lifts will be installed at 19 stations.112 lifts at 58 stations will be upgraded with new operating systems. And new escalators will be installed at Pearse, Connolly and Dún Laoghaire.

It is estimated that lift upgrade works over the next five years will cost €12 million. 

Irish Rail says it will have a contractor in place for upgrade works by this summer with works due to commence later this year.

Candidate Attacks Her Exclusion From Audio Aid for the Visually Impaired Ballot Paper

The audio aid ballot for the visually impaired for Dublin South Central was issued and one of the names of a sitting TDs, Brid Smith, was excluded.

In a statement, Barney Doherty, campaign manager for Brid Smith said:

“This is an affront to democracy. Leaving out the name of a sitting TD on a ballot paper for the visually impaired indicates either gross negligence or unconscious bias.

“I have been informed by the Dublin City Returning Officer that the production of this paper was outsourced to a private company.

“This omission is a deep insult to the visually impaired community as well as an affront to the democratic process itself.

“I am calling on the returning officer to take responsibility. They should make a public statement on the matter and explain how they intend to rectify the situation.”

We could have Ireland’s first left government – with Fine Gael or Fianna Fail gone. That is what all the polls are telling us.

People Before Profit will strongly support the election of Ireland’ first left government.

But we are the only party in this election that is ruling out supporting any coalition with Fianna Fail or Fine Gael.

We have appealed to the Greens, Social Democrats and Sinn Fein to rule it out – but they will not do so. Their leaders have all said they are willing to vote for a FF or FG Taoiseach – if they can strike the right deal.

But once you join the right wing in government you are locked into a system of ‘cabinet responsibility’. This means you must stand over the decisions made by a FF or FG Taoiseach. There is no way out of this.

If the polls are correct, the prospect of a coalition of Fianna Fail with either the Greens, Labour or Social Democrats is a real possibility.

So too, in certain circumstances, is one with SF, despite what Micheal Martin says today.

The best way to Break the Cycle of endless FF/FG rule is to vote NO 1 for People Before Profit and transfer your No 2s and No 3s to other left candidates.

"The Green Party does not have a monopoly on how to tackle climate change - however, there is a growing chasm between how serious the party is taking the issue and the apparent disregard of three big parties for tackling what is officially designated as an emergency."

Sustainability in all and climate action at the heart of everything! We need an economy that is diverse, healthy, and vibrant, and works to serve communities and people over big corporations. A vote for the Greens is a vote to:

🔥 Remove all fossil fuel subsidies and support a global aviation and shipping emissions tax.
🧮 Place more budgetary decision making at local level and that investment favors community ownership of resources.
💶 Introduce a system of regional public banking that supports small businesses and rural Ireland. 
🏠 Reintroduce an 80% windfall tax on rezoned land to reduce the cost of housing.
🏚️ Increase the vacant site levy and implement a site value tax to tackle land hoarding and promote housing completions.
🧓 Implement a new Commission on Tax and Social Welfare to ensure fairness in pensions and the provision of a living wage.
🔟 Pursue a wealth tax on individuals holding assets over €10 million.
🔬 Introduce research and development tax incentives for Small and Medium Enterprises and Irish research institutions. 
🏛️ Reform public procurement to include SMEs.
🏭 Bring in our Just Transition Bill for areas like the Midlands dependent on fossil fuel industries.
🌫️ End fossil fuel subsidies.
🇪🇺 Introduce an EU-wide financial transaction tax on speculative investments.
⬇️ Introduce a lower rate of VAT on the provision of repair services for long life goods.
🌳 Review expenditure and budgets against 2030 international environmental commitments. 

Read more about our vision for an economy that works for people: https://www.greenparty.ie/campaigns/ge2020-economy-for-people/

Why are Gardaí refusing to facilitate student climate protest?

Gardai authorities have informed school students from Fridays for Future that they will not ‘facilitate’ their protest in Dublin.

They claimed that a ‘planned route is highly dangerous and is not recommended’

They also complained a previous protest been infiltrated by an “outside organisation which could have had serious consequences had the Gardaí not intervened”.

This ‘outside’ organisation was not named.

This is a disgraceful and patronising way to treat young people. If Gardai had problem with a particular route, they could easily have simply contacted the organisers with a suggestion for an alternative.

The political establishment thought that the student protest was a ‘once -off’. But as it continues, it's clear they  are worried that it is becoming more radical.

WHY ARE BANKS RIPPING OFF MORTGAGE HOLDERS?

Banks are fleecing many homeowners, forcing mortgage holders to pay an extra €42,000 a year. Here is how it works.

If you borrow money from a European bank, you pay interest at an average rate of 1.5% on your loan.

But Irish banks charge double that, taking an interest of 3% per year.

This means that each month a homeowner is paying an extra €175 a month to the banks.

Over the twenty-year lifetime of their mortgage, that amounts to an extra €42,000. If you are on a 30-year mortgage, you are paying an extra €63,000.  That is two years salary for the average person!

This is exorbitant robbery- sanctioned by Fianna Fail and Fine Gael.

They are also letting banks away with paying no tax for the next ten year  - while they make an annual profit of €2.5 billion a year.

People Before Profit wants to change all this. We will

1.       Bring in a law to insist that banks cannot charge double the European rate.

2.       Immediately impose a minimum corporations tax rate on them.

3.       Take them into public ownership so that cheap credit is available to Irish society.

To follow on from our policies on the arts which we posted earlier this week, we need to talk about public spaces for the arts, and what's required to create a vibrant artistic life in a city.

Too many night-time venues and clubs have closed in the last few years, only to be bulldozed to make way for grey hotels or office blocks.

Local councils must support more performances and exhibitions in public spaces - they should protect existing spaces from greedy developers too. 

To make matters worse, our archaic licensing laws strangle the life out of nightlife. Clubs and other venues close earlier in Dublin than they do anywhere else in Europe. Not only does this deny people the opportunity to access music and entertainment on their terms, it fuels other problems too - like anyone who has seen the city centre after 3AM will attest to. It makes no sense to close all the clubs in the city at once.

We should follow the lead of the Give Us The Night campaign, which calls for positive changes to our night-life.

For working people, the hours in the evening after work are when we are free to enjoy arts and culture but most venues are closed. Galleries, theatres and other cultural spaces should offer late-night openings to better accommodate working people.

The arts and culture belong to the people - let's fund them properly and make them accessible to all!

We have the solutions. Vote People Before Profit number 1 on Saturday and make sure to transfer left.

CHILDCARE - WE NEED INVESTMENT AND A PUBLIC SYSTEM

The Irish model of childcare is broken.

We have the dearest childcare costs in Europe – but some of the worst paid staff.

There is a huge staff turnover, with one survey indicating that two thirds of staff will not continue to work in the sector if the situation does not change.

On top of all that there are problems with insurance and how TUSLA regulations are implemented.

There are two main reasons why there is a crisis:

Ireland lags behind the rest of Europe in its underfunding of childcare. The Irish governments spends just 0.2% of its GDP on childcare – the European average is four times higher.

The Irish model is based on private small businesses – whereas in many other countries there is a public not-for-profit system.

If we address both these issues, we could ensure that costs for parents could drop significantly – and that childcare staff would get a living wage.

Here is what People Before Profit proposes:

Increase investment in childcare services by €800 million immediately. Pay for it through taxes on billionaires, big corporations and vulture funds.

Guarantee each child 33 hours free care in an expanded system.

Over time, integrate privately run creches into a publicly run system of childcare.

Childcare education has never been taken seriously in Ireland because it was assumed that women would stay at home to look after children. When this ethos broke down, the Irish state made little effort to develop a proper childcare system.

Fine Gael and Fianna Fail are ideologically opposed to developing a public system. They know it would mean higher taxes on the wealthy – and so the legacy of their rule is underfunded public services.

Nobody suggests that a child aged 4 is not entitled to free, state run education.

So why is it different for a 3 or 2 years old? It isn’t.

Vote for People Before Profit – the only party who will never prop up FF or FG.

People Before Profit Gives Full Support to Striking Teachers and Lecturers.

The union is entirely right to strike in response to the failure of the government to address pay inequality, which is creating real hardship for young teachers.

Schools are facing real difficulties in recruiting teachers due to the low starting salaries. 

PBP is calling on parents and students to give full support to the teachers and lecturers who will be on strike.

We fully support he teachers in their fight for equal pay.

Young teachers are staring on salaries 14% lower than they would have if they had started in 2011.  

Within the first ten years of their career, they will earn over €50,000 less. Over a 40-year career, they earn over €110,000 less.

All political parties who have been in power since 2010 are responsible for this discrimination against young teachers.

Despite promises, the government has failed to address this discrimination and clearly, the TUI has lost patience. 

We welcome the fact that the ASTI has agreed to ballot for similar action. A sustained campaign of action can lead to the achievement of equal pay.

No trade union can tolerate a situation where two workers doing the same work are paid different rates of pay.

PBP TDs proposed motions in the Dail to end unequal pay but were blocked by the government using the so called “money message”.

All parties must now declare that they will support the immediate abolition of the two  tier pay system.

The government must give a commitment that no sanctions will be taken against striking TUI members arising from the Public Service Pay and Pension Act.

This legislation represents an attack on trade union rights and the right to strike.  PBP will make the repeal of such legislation a priority in the new Dail.

James Connolly appropriately with us today as we launched our program for workers in this country.

People Before Profit will demand: 

1. A Living Wage of €15 an hour 
• End the scandal of low pay • Ireland has the third-highest incidence of low pay in the EU 

2. Equal pay for equal work 
• End the discrimination against new entrants to the public service 
• Close the gender pay gap 

3. The right to retire on a full pension at 65 
• Reverse the increase in the pension age 

4. Increase holidays to the European average• On average European workers get 33.8 days off per year • In high-income countries the average is 34.7 • In Ireland we get 28 

5. Protection from dismissal from day 1 in employment 
• Ireland is almost bottom of the league for the protection of workers against dismissal; • The Unfair Dismissal Act requires, with some exceptions, that employees to be in work for at least a year 

6. A reduction in the working week 
• Irish workers work in excess of EU average hours 
• In high-income countries, the average hours are 120 less per year 
• France has a 35 hour week; Finland is moving to a 4 day week 

7. Full employment rights for migrant works 
• Migrants Right Centre research shows almost half of migrant workers receive less than the minimum wage, almost half have no contract and two-thirds are required to work extra hours without pay 

8. End precarious employment 
• Outlaw “If and When Contracts” • A financial penalty for companies over-reliant on temporary contracts • End bogus self-employment 

9. Mandatory Sick Pay on Full Rates of Pay • Ireland is one of five EU countries where sick pay is not “state-mandated” 
• Replacement levels (the amount of your earnings covered) by sick benefit is 36%, the third-lowest in the EU 

10. Mandatory Maternity Pay on Full Rates of Pay 
• Irish women are not legally entitled to any period of “well-paid” maternity leave. • In only three OECD countries,
The UK, USA, and Ireland is statutory maternity pay less than 35% of normal pay • Paternity and parental leave should also be paid at the full rate 

11. Mandatory union recognition • Ireland has one of the most restrictive collective bargaining legislation compared to other European countries and even further afield • Ireland has one of the lowest levels of Collective Bargaining coverage in the EU 

12. The Right to Strike • Repeal the 1990 Industrial Relations Act to allow for secondary action and the right to take strike action on political issues such as housing • Repeal the Public Services Pay and Pension Act 2017 and FEMPI legislation to remove sanctions against public sector workers who go on strike.

Transforming Ireland's transport system isn't just about cutting emissions - it's about radically improving people's mobility, their independence, and their quality of life. The TomTom Traffic Index for 2019 has today listed Dublin as the most congested city in Western Europe, and the 17th most congested city in the world. And the government's solution? Build more roads.

Today, our transport spokesperson Patrick Costello launched our Transport Policy, which laid out a vision for an alternative transport future - not just for Ireland, but for all of Europe. 

"We’ve had a transport minister for the past three years with no interest in doing anything about Dublin's gridlock - bar building more roads," said Cllr. Costello. "What’s needed is a radical rebalancing of priorities, supporting lots of different ways of getting about the city, rewarding and making it safe to cycle, walk, take public transport, and use other options that will help people get off our roads when they can.”

If we are to address the challenge of decarbonising our economy while improving the lives of our citizens, we need to dramatically alter the direction of our national transport policy.
🚌🚃🚄🚲🛴♿️🚶‍♂️
Today we launched our action plan to do just that. Investing in our transport system is the opportunity of a generation to deliver quality of life and tackle climate change. The Green Party will overhaul Ireland’s fragmented transport system, making public transport a real option for the vast majority of people, in both urban and rural settings, and ending our reliance on fossil fuels.

#WantGreenVoteGreen #GE2020

The first five years of a child’s life are really magical. They are also very expensive for parents. We’ll increase State support to take some of the financial pressure off and ease the worries of mothers and fathers.

Fianna Fáil will:

✔️ Quadruple weekly subsidy for every child (under 3) in a crèche from €20 to €80.
✔️ Under FF, State will subsidise this by over 40% putting money in parents pockets.
✔️ Introduce a new €2000 per year tax credit for workers whose child is being minded by a registered child minder – equivalent to €166 per month.
✔️ Extend the successful ECCE scheme, introduced originally by Fianna Fáil for 3 to 5 year olds by 2 weeks per year to 40 weeks.
✔️ Increase maternity and paternity leave to a total of 34 weeks – to be shared at discretion of parents.

People Before Profit remembers those injured and murdered by the Parachute regiment on the streets of Derry 48 years ago today.

John 'Jackie' Duddy - age 17. Shot as he ran away from soldiers in the car park of Rossville Flats. The bullet struck him in the shoulder and entered his chest. Three witnesses said they saw a soldier take deliberate aim at the youth as he ran. He was the first fatality on Bloody Sunday.

Michael Kelly - age 17. Shot in the stomach while standing at the rubble barricade on Rossville Street.

Hugh Gilmour - age 17. Shot as he ran away from soldiers near the rubble barricade. The bullet went through his left elbow and entered his chest.

William Nash - age 19. Shot in the chest at the rubble barricade. Three people were shot while going to his aid, including his father Alexander Nash.

John Young - age 17. Shot in the face at the rubble barricade while crouching and going to the aid of William Nash.

Michael McDaid - age 20. Shot in the face at the rubble barricade, while crouching and going to the aid of William Nash.

Kevin McElhinney - age 17. Shot from behind, near the rubble barricade, while attempting to crawl to safety.

James 'Jim' Wray - age 22. Shot in the back while running away from soldiers in Glenfada Park. He was then shot again in the back as he lay mortally wounded on the ground. Jim Wray was calling out that he could not move his legs before he was shot the second time.

William McKinney - age 27. Shot in the back as he attempted to flee through Glenfada Park.

Gerard McKinney - age 35. Shot in the chest at Abbey Park. A soldier ran through an alleyway from Glenfada Park and shot him from a few yards away. Witnesses said that when he saw the soldier, McKinney stopped and held up his arms, shouting "Don't shoot! Don't shoot!", before being shot. The bullet went through his body and struck Gerard Donaghy behind him.

Gerard Donaghy - age 17. Shot in the stomach at Abbey Park while standing behind Gerard McKinney. Both were struck by the same bullet. Bystanders brought Donaghy to a nearby house, where he was examined by a doctor. The doctor opened Donaghy's clothes to examine him, and his pockets were also searched for identification. Two bystanders then attempted to drive Donaghy to hospital, but the car was stopped at an Army checkpoint. They were ordered to leave the car and a soldier drove it to a Regimental Aid Post, where an Army medical officer pronounced Donaghy dead. Soldiers planted nail bombs on Donaghy to justify the killings.

Patrick Doherty - age 31. Shot from behind while attempting to crawl to safety in the forecourt of Rossville Flats. He was shot by soldiers who came out of Glenfada Park. Doherty was photographed, moments before and after he died, by French journalist Gilles Peress. Despite testimony from "Soldier F" that he had shot a man holding a pistol, Widgery acknowledged that the photographs show Doherty was unarmed, and that forensic tests on his hands for gunshot residue proved negative.

Bernard 'Barney' McGuigan - age 41. Shot in the head when he walked out from cover to help Patrick Doherty. He had been waving a white handkerchief to indicate his peaceful intentions.

John Johnston - age 59. Shot in the leg and left shoulder on William Street 15 minutes before the rest of the shooting started. Johnston was not on the march, but on his way to visit a friend in Glenfada Park. He died on 16 June 1972; his death has been attributed to the injuries he received on the day. He was the only one not to die immediately or soon after being shot.

We'll never forget.

- The fight for justice continues.

People Before Profit Gives Full Support to Striking Teachers and Lecturers. 

The union is entirely right to strike in response to the failure of the government to address pay inequality, which is creating real hardship for young teachers.

Schools are facing real difficulties in recruiting teachers due to the low starting salaries. 

PBP is calling on parents and students to give full support to the teachers and lecturers who will be on strike.

All political parties who have been in power since 2010 are responsible for this discrimination against young teachers.

Despite promises, the government has failed to address this discrimination and clearly, the TUI has lost patience. 

We welcome the fact that the ASTI has agreed to ballot for similar action.  A sustained campaign of action can lead to the achievement of equal pay.

No trade union can tolerate a situation where two workers doing the same work are paid different rates of pay.

PBP TDs proposed motions in the Dail to end unequal pay but were blocked by the government using the so called “money message”.

All parties must now declare that they will support the immediate abolition of the two tier pay system.

PBP say that the government must give a commitment that no sanctions will be taken against striking TUI members arising from the Public Service Pay and Pension Act.

This legislation represents an attack on trade union rights and the right to strike.  People Before Profit will make the repeal of such legislation a priority in the new Dail.

Today we launched a policy paper outlining the cost of climate inaction to Ireland's economy. From extreme weather events to poor quality housing, and the health implications and lack of public transport that impact people's quality of life.

Today is the 5th anniversary of the Jobstown protest. In the context of a need for new mass movements around housing, the climate, workers' rights and inequality generally, we look back on the protest and see what lessons can be learned for today.

The fundamental cause of the climate crisis is the unsustainable capitalist system, based on private ownership and the endless pursuit of profit. Today we took our Green campaign to beautiful Bull Island to launch our biodiversity policy. Ireland is in the midst of a biodiversity emergency. We must take urgent action to halt the loss of diversity in our bio systems, we must RESTORE, PROTECT, and HELP NATURE THRIVE.
🌿🐝🐌
Bull Island is a National Bird Sanctuary, a Biosphere reserve, a National Nature Reserve, and a Special Area of Conservation under the EU Habitats Directive, but it faces immense pressures from issues like plastic pollution, rising sea levels and poor water qualitiy, and its bird populations are threatened by over fishing.

IRISH BANKS HIKE INTEREREST RATES IN GREED FOR PROFIT

Irish banks are engaged in a massive scam to rob customers by charging exorbitant interest rates.

Last year, the head of the Central Bank, Philip Lane, reported that banks had paid out a staggering €120 million in compensation to mortgage holders who were pushed off tracker rates.

These tie interest rates on mortgages to the current very low rates being charged by the European Central Bank.

Yet despite this acknowledgement of massive fraud, AIB continued to charge the ‘wrong’ tracker rate to customers, extracting an extra €500 from them.

The Central bank has acknowledged that over 10,000 mortgage holders have been charged the wrong tracker rate.

There has been no reported case of the ‘mistaken’ rate being to the advantage of the customer.

Mortgage holders who have a variable mortgage are even in a worse position.

These are charged a 3.35 percent interest rate on their mortgages while the equivalent interest rate in the euro area is 1.83 per cent.

On a €200,000 mortgage, the extra interest premium amounts to a charge of €250 a month or €3,000 a year.

Despite the use of a polite language about ‘mistakes’ and apologies when these scandals come to light, the reality is that banks are engaged in massive fraud.

They are making ordinary people pay for the speculative activities they engaged in during the Celtic Tiger.

The aim is to push for higher profits in order to pave the way to eventual privatisation.

Leo Varadkar’s government has actively conspired with banks to ‘squeeze the middle’ by refusing to intervene in this scandal.

The next time his PR machine makes reference to the ‘squeezed middle’, we should be clear who is doing the ‘squeezing’.

Our Green Party #GE2020 candidate for Galway West Cllr Pauline O'Reilly is featured in today's Irish Times, highlighting the negative impact that short-term letting services like Air BnB are having on cities like Galway. 

The service has become "a free-for-all", she says, "hollowing out" the city centre and exacerbating the housing crisis as residents are pushed out to accommodate tourists. 

“Even though we have regulations in place since July it is true to say that tourism lets are effectively still unregulated in Galway city, and indeed right across the country," said Cllr O'Reilly.

“This is having a deeper impact here in Galway as we experience higher tourism numbers than other parts of the country - especially with Galway 2020 coming next year."

She continues: "This is the wrong way to do planning. We need to see people living where the services are."

https://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/galway-city-being-hollowed-out-by-short-term-lets-1.4137626

Read our election manifesto in full.

If elected, our TDs pledge to do the following:

➡️ Make housing a human right: Propose a bill for proper rent controls and security of tenure; fight to stop the sell-off of public land; propose a national construction company to build affordable houses; hold a referendum to enshrine a right to housing in the constitution.

➡️ End the two-tier health system: Fight for a national health service, free at the point of use, publicly owned and democratically run; hire more frontline staff; increase pay to cut hospital waiting lists.

➡️ Take radical action for the climate – for people and planet: Fight for free public transport and more buses; provide proper grants to fund deep-retrofitting of houses.; stop the importation of fracked gas; create a just transition for workers and farmers; put a carbon tax on the big polluters, not on ordinary people.

➡️ Provide a fair deal for the elderly: Restore the pension age to 65; increase the state pension to €260 a week; restore the transitional pension scheme.

➡️ Create a living wage and job security: Fight to scrap Croke Park hours for public servants; insist on increasing the minimum wage to a living wage of €15 an hour; abolish USC tax for those under €90,000 and introduce a high-income charge for those over it.

➡️ Guarantee 33 hours of free childcare per week: Cap fees at 3% of income and then move to a free service through a National Childcare Service.

➡️ Education for lifelong learning: Fight to scrap third level fees; raise the SUSI grants and eligibility thresholds; insist on smaller class sizes in schools.

➡️ Guarantee real equality for people with disabilities and special needs: Ensure public transport is accessible to all; hire more Special Needs Assistants; guarantee early assessment and intervention for autism and disabilities.

➡️ Abolish unjust taxes and end rip off insurance: Fight to scrap the property tax on family homes; propose a publicly owned insurance company to cut costs.

https://manifesto.pbp.ie/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Paople-Before-Profit-General-Election-Manifesto-2020.pdf

FIANNA FAIL- THE PRETEND OPPOSITION

Fine Gael and Fianna Fail are partners and share the same conservative policies.

But now Fianna Fail present themselves a party of change, capable of leading a new government.

Their record tells a different story.

Fianna Fail started the attack on social housing and by the time they left office, 98,318 households were on the housing list.

Fianna Fail started the run down of the health service, promoting ‘co-located’ private hospitals on the site of public hospitals.

Fianna Fail supported the increase in the retirement age to 67 and eventually 68.

Fianna Fail loaded the Irish people with €64 billion in debt after they demanded that we ‘re-capitalise’ banks.

Fianna Fail did a deal with the Bishops to ‘indemnify’ them against the cost of claims on child abuse.

The party has a long record of corruption.

Its former leader, Charlie Huaghey took bribes worth €8 million.

Another, Bertie Ahern, could not explain a €30,000 donation that appeared weeks after a meeting with a property developer.

Their former press officer, Frank Dunlop, was jailed for corruption.

Three of its TDs, Liam Lawlor, Ray Burke, and Ivor Callely have been jailed various forms of corruption.

Micheal Martin goes back a long way, starting out as a Minister in 1997. He associated with many of these people but saw or heard nothing? 

Replacing FG with FF is like swapping a snob for a crook – it makes no difference.

THE BORES SHOW

The Virgin Media debate between Varadkar and Martin was more like two branch managers of a bank comparing notes. It was dreary and boring.

The lack of real political choice was evident when Varadkar offered Martin a grand coalition if Fine Gael could not get a majority with Labour and the Greens.

The only reason why Martin did not accept was because he is still pretending to be the ‘ leader of the opposition’.

The debate showed just three things:

First they both acknowledged that FF, FG Labour and the Greens had all backed the move to increase the pension age to 68.

The FF-Green government originally proposed it. Then Joan Burton Labour Party leader introduced it in Social Welfare and Pension Act in 2011, which FG voted for.

The only way to restore the pension age to 65, is to vote for the left alternative to these parties.

Second, they both wanted to appear nice to the Greens. Martin was the most fulsome in his praise because his party is already forging an alliance with the Greens at local level. 

In Dublin City Council, for example, the FF-Labour-Green coalition voted to sell off public land at Devaney Gardens.

Third, both Varadkar and Martin attacked Sinn Fein and ruled out a border poll. Their attacks on Sinn Fein - who were not present – was a disgrace.

But Mary Lou McDonald should draw a clear conclusion from this – Sinn Fein should stop asking to join FF or FG in government. They should join up with the left and promote a call to ‘Break the Cycle’ of FF and FG.

EVER WONDERED WHAT THE ESTABLISHMENT 'CLOSING RANKS' LOOKS LIKE?

In 2016, televised debates included a range of parties. Fianna Fáil and Fine Gael combined received less than 50% of the first preference vote for the first time in the history of the Irish state. The establishment now wishes to shore up support for Ireland's two right wing parties by excluding other groups from the official election narrative.

After the last election, the Solidarity-PBP alliance was fifth largest party in Ireland, (based on first-preference vote share and number of seats). For our part, we are being excluded from many polls and debates and getting far less coverage than parties who received a lower vote share than us.

Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil are happy for the debate to be limited to their essentially ideologically identical politics and appear not to want to debate with anyone who who is even just outside of their ideological realm.

It is shameful that Ireland's media denies a platform to politics outside of the neoliberal limits of the Fianna Fáil/Fine Gael debate. It also shows how rattled the Irish establishment is. They are eager to protect the status quo and return to the days of domination of two parties.

Let's make sure we get the word out there that there is an alternative to the traditional right wing rulers of Ireland. Speak to everyone you can and urge them not to give any of their preferences to the parties who have wrecked living standards in Ireland or to those who will prop them up. 

#BreakTheCycle

New Green TD for Dublin Fingal, Joe O'Brien, has won a discrimination case against Irish Rail under the Equal Status Acts, and will now be contacting the Irish Human Rights and Equality Commission to see what role they can play in pushing Irish Rail to make its services more accessible to all.

"I heard and continue to hear so many stories of older people and people with disabilities not able to access the rail service because of faulty or inaccessible lifts," said Deputy O'Brien. "It was really for them that I took this case in the summer. When people complain to Irish Rail about this ongoing situation the answers are frankly not good enough.

"Every day there are roughly 6-8 stations where the lifts are out of order or inaccessible. Between January 2018 and July 2019 the lifts at Skerries train station were out of order on a total of 27 different occasions."

Tax the Billionaires

A new report by Oxfam indicates that Ireland has the fifth highest number of billionaires per head of population in the world.

But under Ireland’s notorious tax exile rule, many do not pay tax.

A study of 450 ‘high net worth’ individuals by the Irish Revenue Commissioners in 2011 found that 54 have declared themselves resident abroad.

These include Denis O’ Brien who is officially declared as a tax resident of Malta. Dermot Desmond resides for tax purposes in Gibraltar. John Magnier has chosen Switzerland.

In response to growing outrage, the government imposed a ‘domicile levy’ to extract some money from the wealthy.

But this has fallen into disrepair as the both the money raised and the numbers of millionaires paying declined. In 2010, 32 individuals paid €3.43 million in tax but by 2015 just 13 individuals paid €2.30 million.

The Comptroller and Auditor General subsequently revealed that of 334 High Net Worth Individuals, 83 paid less tax in 2015 than the average PAYE worker on €36,500.

Ireland has become a tax dodging haven for very wealthy individuals and big corporations. But middle income workers end up paying high rates of tax.

People Before Profit want to cut the USC tax on workers earning below €90,000. To help pay for it, we will end the tax exile rule, impose a wealth tax and higher income tax bands on those earning over €90,000.

It is time we had some tax justice.

Our employment proposals:

Whether you are a traditional manual worker or a white-collar worker, you need greater protection. Yet low pay is on the rise, particularly for the young. Many are in precarious, insecure employment. Instead of a government that looks after corporations, we need one that ensures workers have more rights. People Before Profit support strong unions that stand up for workers’ rights. Today, many union leaders have become too close to employers and the government. They need to become more democratic and fight for their members. Workers should also have a right to freedom of association – to join a union of their choice. We will support the following legislative changes:

➡️ Ban discrimination – pay parity and restoration now: Public sector workers hired after 2011 are paid less than those who joined before. Additionally, some public sector workers are paid less than similarly qualified workers. Nurses and teachers were right to strike for pay parity and restoration. We would repeal FEMPI terms and support public sector workers in their call for pay parity and restoration.

➡️ End the gender pay gap: It is completely unacceptable that women are paid less than men for doing the same work. This in-built sexism needs to be weeded out through legislation, union action and cultural changes.

➡️ Give all workers equal rights from day one: Whether you are part-time or full-time, temporary or permanent, you should have the same legal rights so that work conditions are not driven down.

➡️ Guarantee unions the right to access all workplaces: Unions should have the right to enter a workplace at least once a year to put the case for why people should join. They should also be able to inspect for adherence to labour legislation.

➡️ Recognise unions for bargaining: When at least 20 percent of the workers join a union, they should have a right to collectively bargain with their employer through their chosen union.

➡️ Ban zero-hour contracts: Workers have a right to a guaranteed number of hours per week.

➡️ Legislate for four extra holidays a year: With an annual right to 29 days holidays, workers in Ireland have one of the lowest entitlements in Europe. Give workers a statutory right to bereavement leave.

➡️ Raise the minimum wage to the living wage: A living wage is calculated on what one needs for a socially acceptable standard of living. It amounts to €12.30 an hour.

➡️ Pay for internships: They are often used to exploit and dash the hopes of the young. They are also a free subsidy to businesses who get cheap labour.

➡️ Bring labour agencies back into the public sector: End the practice of giving a bounty to private companies who force social welfare recipients to take up unsuitable jobs.

➡️ Reform the Insolvency Act and Companies Act: Workers should not be at the back of the queue. They should get the payments they are entitled to in redundancy situations.

➡️ Introduce maximum 5:1 pay ratios in the public sector so that top managers do not earn more than five times those on junior grades. Only award state contracts to private firms who adhere to this.

➡️ Change Industrial Relations Legislation: Abolish the 1990 Industrial Relations Act, which restrains workers from standing up for themselves. Stop companies taking out injunctions against workers and give workers a right to express solidarity.

➡️ Return the retirement age to 65: Protect workers’ pension rights.

14 January 2020

Press statement:

Potential disenfranchisement of many thousands of electors a scandal that must be averted

Draft registers must be incorporated by all local authorities and supplementary register facility must be provided

Responding to the scenario that many thousands of potential electors may be disenfranchised in the forthcoming election by the non inclusion of those who registered in recent months as well as the non availability of the supplementary register facility Solidarity TD for Cork North Central Mick Barry TD said:

"It has been a positive feature of recent votes such as on marriage equality and repeal that tens if not hundreds of thousands of predominately young people registered in time to exercise their franchise and furthermore that special measures to facilitate a late surge of registrations were put in place.

"The contrast in terms of this election is stark. The non-availability of the supplementary register facility is bad enough. The news that those who registered late last year mindful of the likelihood of an election early this year and are currently on the draft register may be excluded is scandalous.

Dublin West Solidarity TD Ruth Coppinger added:

"I welcome the promise of Dublin City Council and Fingal that they would do what it takes to include all those on the draft register but it only throws into sharp relief the perversity of some or most local authorities across the state not similarly acting.

"Many of those who registered late or who would ordinarily use the supplementary register facility are the youngest cohort of potential voters but also renters. The mass exclusion of this category will serve to politically skew the results which I suspect will not overly disturb the government. It is not acceptable and a commitment from the Minister responsible for local government Eoghan Murphy must commit today to provide the local authorities whatever they need to ensure maximum participation."

Our housing proposals:

• Hold a referendum to insert a ‘right to housing’ clause into the Irish constitution: Human rights do not just include political freedoms – the state should have a legal obligation to provide housing.
• Immediately declare a housing emergency: This will enable the state to borrow funds to begin a major house-building programme and to withdraw from paying out €500 million a year to private landlords.
• Create a national construction company: There is no reason why the state cannot build houses. State-owned land is available and tens of thousands of construction workers either here or abroad who would be willing to work for decent wages.
• Build 100,000 council houses over five years: This will cost €3 billion in the first year and a total of €14 billion over five years, but it will become self-financing by year six and into the future. This programme will also provide jobs in the construction sector and add to revenue receipts.
• Control the price of building land to create affordable housing: You can build a three-bedroomed house for less than €200,000. If speculation in land were stopped, we could have cheaper housing.
• Force NAMA to hand over land for public housing: This is public land – it should be used to build council houses cheaply.
• Stop the sell-off of public land to private developers: Fine Gael wants to sell off as much public land as cheaply as possible to their developer friends. This must be stopped. Public land should be used for council and affordable housing and community amenities.
• Implement rent controls and provide security of tenure: Rents are too high. The poor are being forced out of their communities. We would freeze the rents immediately and create a system whereby tenants can seek a cut in rents. 
• Create an independent review board for council tenants: At present, tenants cannot appeal decisions of their landlord – the local authorities. 
• Establish an Independent National Housing Agency to oversee the delivery of safe and culturally appropriate Traveller Accommodation.
• Ban economic evictions: Vulture funds are trying to increase the rate of evictions because property prices have risen. Landlords use loopholes such as renovations to evict tenants. If passed in the Dáil, the Solidarity-People Before Profit Anti-Eviction Bill would have closed these loopholes and banned evictions in cases of demonstrable economic distress. We will continue to fight to stem the tide of evictions.
• Impose a vacant dwelling levy: There are over 200,000 vacant properties in Ireland – even though thousands have no home. We need a ‘use it or lose it’ policy whereby private property owners will pay a special levy if their property is left empty for more than six months. We would impose a vacant land levy of 25 percent to be charged on land that is being held back for speculative reasons.
• Use Compulsory Purchase Orders: In some cases a levy will not be enough. If the public good demands it, the state should be able to use a CPO to attain appropriate accommodation.
• Reverse the scandal of self-certification of building works: Conduct immediate audits for fire and safety. Create a redress fund for the 90,000 houses built during the Celtic Tiger era that have serious defects. Levy the construction industry for this fund.

Read our general election manifesto at www.pbp.ie

Fight climate change and inequality 

A Green new deal

While the government locks us into decades of fossil fuel infrastructure with the Shannon LNG project, it should come to no surprise to anyone that once again Ireland has failed to meet emissions reductions targets. While the political establishment is forcing regressive carbon taxes on ordinary people, they're planning on spending over €120m on carbon credits (licenses to excessively pollute) in 2019 alone. 

We don't need neoliberal greenwashing, we need real climate action. A Green New Deal with socialist policies that puts social and economic justice at the heart of the fight against climate change is the only way forward.

As revealed on RTÉ's 'Hot Air' documentary last night, we're on a road to nowhere with the Government's insistence on sticking with a transport policy that puts roads above public transport and safe cycling infrastructure. 

Today in the Dáil, Green Party leader Eamon Ryan questioned the logic of widening the M11 instead of investing in public transport, pointing out:

🚗 It doesn't make climate sense.
🚙 It doesn't make transport sense.
🚕 It doesn't make economic sense.

🌍🔥 RTÉ's excellent 'Hot Air' documentary on Ireland's climate crisis highlighted failure after failure from a government that either hasn't managed to get to grips with how serious and urgent the climate crisis is, or just doesn't want to take real, serious action.

🌍🔥 The science is clear, Ireland has the know-how to take action, but we have a government that just won't rise to the challenge.

🌍 "We have the know-how. We just have to choose to do it." 

🌍 We've been saying it for years: Ireland could be good at this! We just need the political will to take us from climate laggards to climate leaders.

🌍 #RTEonClimate continues at 9.35 tonight with 'Hot Air: Ireland's Climate Crisis', where Philip Boucher Hayes examines the ever-growing gulf between the climate action we should be taking, and what our government and industries are actually doing. Then stay tuned for Prime Time at 10.35, where Green Party Deputy Leader Catherine Martin joins the panel to discuss the scale of the challenge and the solutions we urgently need to be considering.

It doesn’t have to be this way. 

People do not have to suffer.

There are solutions to this crisis - rent reduction alongside a rent freeze, a large-scale public housing build programme and legislation to clip the wings of vulture funds to name a few. 

What is needed now is the political will to make a difference. It is time for the government to act.

Earlier today Ruth Coppinger TD paid a visit to the emergency department in Connolly hospital in Blanchardstown. 

We have been told by hospital sources that the hospital has had to cancel a huge number of elective procedures: including very serious operations such as hysterectomies.

There has been a 6% increase in the number of A&E incidents last year with no increased investment. This is effectively a cut. That figure would have been greater if there was a greater cold snap. 

In this election we need to demand investment in the health service to make up for the huge amount of demographic changes that have taken place in Ireland.

Between 2017 and 2018 Novartis' profits increased by over 40% - up to $12.6 billion! Just three days ago, it raised its earnings forecast!  This also comes on the back of Molex - another profitable company - announcing 500 job losses at Shannon. 

If these companies want to shed workers they should immediately open their books for review to see where its money is going. If they insist on going ahead with the job losses then we should bring its assets into public ownership in order to protect those jobs and even expand employment through public investment. The neoliberal economic model that leaves workers at the mercy of the whims of big multinational companies is a failure, we need a socialist plan for economic development that acts in the interests of people, not profits.

0.9% of the population owns nearly half the world, where the bottom 54% own just 1.8%. Capitalism as a system is fundamentally unsustainable and unjust, it's a system where millions starve a year while the top 1% accumulate endless wealth. The only way to fight this inequality is radical socialist change.

In Ireland, the wealth of the richest grew by 10% in just the last year alone, while at the same time people are in precarious work and rents are skyrocketing. It's not a coincidence!

The movement for a Green New Deal is international. If we're going to fight this climate catastrophe, we can't rely on neoliberal and regressive carbon taxes, we need radical action - a Green New Deal with socialist policies!

"Have we finally copped on to the fact that our very existence, and that of future generations, is now in question?"

That's the question being asked tonight, as 'Climate Week' kicks off on RTÉ, beginning a week of programming that looks at the impact of climate change on Ireland and around the world. 

Tune into 'Will Ireland Survive 2050' on RTÉ One at 9.35 and watch UCD climate scientist Cara Augustenborg and Met Éireann's Ger Flemming look at the consequences of ever more extreme weather events on the stability of our planet and our society, and how that may affect us 30 years from now.

The Irish Independent was on the campaign trail with our Dublin Fingal candidate, Cllr. Joe O'Brien, ahead of the by-elections on November 29th. Voters in Dublin Fingal have the chance to elect a strong, Green voice to represent them in the Dáil, pushing for more public transport and better, more sustainable development.

"There is housing going up, but it's the same old problem in that the infrastructure isn't going in," says Joe.

As the closure of two peat-powered Midlands power stations is announced, our Offaly Senator Pippa Hackett has called on the Government to back the Green Party's Just Transition Bill and to establish a permanent Just Transition Commission.

“Today is a devastating day for these workers and their families," says Senator Hackett. "We welcome the fact that they hope to avoid compulsory redundancies and that a Just Transition Commissioner has been appointed, but providing a Just Transition means more than just moving people or giving a pay-out. It needs to be about supporting the community and giving people a future there. That’s why we need a permanent Just Transition Commission looking for and working with communities that are facing a change and building alternatives where they are."

A SPECIAL AWARD FOR TAX DODGING

Tim Cooke, the chief Executive officer of the giant firm Apple, will fly into Ireland at the end of the month to get a special award from Leo Varadkar.

He will be presented with the ’inaugural IDA Ireland Special Recognition Award’ at a  special ceremony.

Apple owes the Irish people €13 billion in back taxes and this is now locked away in an ‘escrow’ account.

The Irish state has paid out huge sums to legal firms to mount a case to ensure that they did not receive a penny from Apple. 

Between 2014 and 2018, €5.8 million of taxpayers’ money was doled out to Irish legal and consultancy firms. 

This is only the start of a drip feed of lucrative state contracts as the Finance Minister, Pascal Donohoe, promised that 'the case will continue to be resourced as appropriate.’

Nothing better sums up the politics of Fianna Fail and Fine Gael. 

They will spend millions in legal fees to ensure that money due to the Irish people is not paid.

If Apples paid out the €13 billion it owes, plus the extra few billion in interest payments, the housing crisis could be solved quickly.

That will only happen if we break the cycle of FF and FG rule.

What's now being called "Vote Gate" is a classic example for the establishment's antipathy for formal democratic processes. 

Unfortunately, that's far from the worst that they're at over in the Dáil - the government has managed to de facto kill over 50 bills in the Dáil with its infamous "money message". Whenever the government loses a notable vote they insist that the legislation that gets passed requires some money to be spent, therefore requiring a "money message" from the executive approving it - which Fine Gael then refuses to give!

The way Fine Gael have been using the money message for years has been to exercise an anti-democratic veto over votes that they lose in the Dáil - and their pals in Fianna Fáil are happy to back them up on it!

Ever wonder why the bus is late to your stop? One of the main reasons is that Dublin City is the third most congested city on the entire planet. With inadequate public transport infrastructure, people are driven into cars and that itself drives down the effectiveness of existing public transport!

If we want proper functioning public transport, it needs to be frequent, free, green and publicly owned so that it can be efficiently planned. It needs major investment that brings people out of cars, driving down costs, congestion and carbon emissions.

Figures released by the Environmental Protection Agency have revealed that Ireland exceeded its annual greenhouse gas emissions allocation by 5 million tonnes in 2018, proving yet again that the Government is way off track when it comes to rapidly decarbonising the economy. 

❎ Missing these emissions targets for the third year in a row means the State will now be forced to pay hundreds of millions of euros in fines.

❎ Household emissions increased by 7.9% last year. 

As winters get colder, we need a national-scale retrofitting scheme that would help householders to reduce their energy costs AND their emissions.

❎ Transport emissions increased by 1.7% last year. 

We need to urgently flip our transport budget 2-to-1 in favour of spending on public transport and walking and cycling infrastructure.

❎ Agriculture emissions increased by 1.9% last year.

We need to overhaul our agriculture system to support the switch to low-carbon, nature-friendly farming practices that put family farms and the environment at the heart of agricultural policy.

HOUSING- VOTE GENUINE LEFT

Housing is one of the big issues in this election and, suddenly, all parties are showing ‘concern’.

But here are the facts:

Homelessness has grown from 3,500 people  in 2011 to 10,250 today.

Dublin has the third highest rents in Europe. The rest the country is not far behind.

Most young people can no longer buy a house. Many stay with their parents into their 30s.

The reason for the crisis is that Fine Gael and Fine Fail rely on the private market for solutions.

One in three of their TDs are landlords and they oppose any genuine rent controls.

Both parties ganged up to stop a Solidarity-People Before Profit bill to put a  right to housing bill into the constitution.

But there are real solutions and they come from the left.

People Before Profit want to stop the sale of public land to private developers. This land could be used to be build thousands of social and affordable houses cheaply.

The price of building land around cities should be controlled. Today, speculators apply to re-zone land and then sit back while land values increase.

There could be proper rent controls that allow people to apply for rent cuts. If a tenant can show that rents consume more than one third of their income – which international research indicates is below poverty line -  they should be able to apply for a cut.

These solutions entail a break with a policy of ‘not interfering in the market’ and that is why conservative parties like Fianna Fail and Fine Gael oppose them.

But if you want left policies, you need to vote for the genuine left.

In heat of the election battle, others will say they are opposed to selling off public land.

But councillors from Labour, Greens, Social Democrats and even Sinn Fein have voted to sell off public land.

The one party that stands strong for genuine left policies is Solidarity-People Before Profit.

Fianna Fáil TD for Offaly Barry Cowen TD has secured a new Just Transition Fund for the Midlands as part of Budget 2020. Deputy Cowen was a key part of the Fianna Fáil budget negotiation team in the talks.

A total of €31m in funding will be focused on the midlands region. The new fund will be focused on social housing retrofits, peatland rehabilitation and the local economy. It will have an independent Just Transition Commissioner to oversee the fund. The main aim will be to plan, invest and implement a transition to alternative and sustainable jobs in different sectors that will protect and enhance the economy of the region.

Commenting on the news Deputy Cowen stated “We fought long and hard to ensure that the transition to a green economy in the midlands is given the support it needs. I am happy to confirm that after direct talks with the Minister for Finance over the past number of weeks Fianna Fáil has secured a new fund for Offaly and the surrounding counties.

“€20m will be dedicated to the creation of a new energy efficiency scheme targeted, initially, at the social housing stock in the region. This will create new, sustainable employment in the region. €5m for peatland rehabilitation and €6m to a flexible fund to be focused on those local priorities.

“It is estimated that this new investment will support over 400 environmentally sustainable jobs, with up to 100 more jobs through expanded peatlands rehabilitation.

“The midlands has a proud tradition of work with Bord Na Mona that stretches back for decades and across countless households. We now need to prepare for the transition to a green economy that promotes employment and invests in communities. This is a key test for our state to show that we can change to a green pathway while protecting jobs and communities affected by that transition,” Deputy Cowen concluded.

Fianna Fáil Health Spokesperson @stephen_donnelly_wicklow has welcomed the €25 million increase in the National Treatment Purchase Fund (NTPF) in Budget 2020. This is the fourth successive increase secured by Fianna Fáil under the Confidence and Supply arrangement.

Deputy Donnelly said, “There are approximately one million people on waiting lists – that’s just under a quarter of our entire population. Fine Gael have presided over the highest waiting lists ever seen in this country.

“In 2016, following a 38% increase in inpatient/day case waiting lists under the tenure of then Health Minister Leo Varadkar, Fianna Fáil secured the reactivation of the National Treatment Purchase Fund in the Confidence and Supply Arrangement.

“In each successive year we have secured an increase in funding for it and we know that it is working – the inpatient day case list has fallen from a high of over 86,000 in 2017 to just under 69,000 in August.

“I also want to welcome the reduction in prescription charges and the €10 reduction in the threshold for the drug payment scheme. These measures are a key part of Sláintecare and Fianna Fáil has been looking for progress on them. By seeking action and progress in these areas, we have been condemned by Fine Gael TDs as “reckless”. I look forward to them now voicing the same vitriol concern with Minister Donohoe for taking action on them today”, he concluded.

Fianna Fáil Spokesperson on Communications, #ClimateAction & Environment @timmydooleytd says his party was instrumental in ensuring that revenues from an increase in #carbontax will be ringfenced for specific #environmental measures.

Deputy Dooley says this money must be used to ensure that people at risk of fuel poverty are protected, that those in communities affected by a reduction in peat and coal fired electricity generation are helped as part of a just transition; and to encourage people to adapt their behaviour towards a more #environmentallyfriendly way of living. #budget2020

“Fianna Fáil has always had a strong record on climate change measures. We first introduced a carbon tax in 2010 and recognised the need to increase the tax once the revenues are set aside for specific climate action measures. We stood firm on this position and are pleased to have secured this provision in Budget 2020”, said Deputy Dooley.

BREAKING: After questioning Commission representatives at a Committee session in the European Parliament today, Green MEP Ciarán Cuffe has established that it IS within the power of the Irish government to STOP the Shannon LNG project from going ahead and making Ireland a gateway for fracked natural gas from the US.

“The Fine Gael-led Government has misled the Irish people in suggesting that the decision-making process around granting special status for the Shannon LNG project rests with the European Commission," says Cuffe. 

"As a result of my questioning of the Commission representatives at Committee today, it is clear that the Government is attempting to pass the buck on this hugely problematic matter. Just last week, the Swedish government refused permission for a similar plant for the Port of Gothenburg. The Irish government must follow suit."

The Green Party's Seanad nominee and Agriculture Spokesperson Cllr. Pippa Hackett has today called on Minister Josepha Madigan to reverse her decision to allow the netting of hares for coursing this season, despite the threat posed to this protected species by Rabbit Haemorrhagic Disease.

"Minister Madigan has an abysmal record on wildlife protection, and this decision is a total abuse of power and a reckless act of wildlife vandalism," said Cllr. Hackett. Recent comments by Eamon Ryan regarding rural car-sharing schemes have been badly misrepresented this week, online and in the media. We deeply regret the hurt this has caused to rural communities, but the fact is, these reports have been wildly inaccurate. 

Here's why.

THOUSANDS COULD BE STOPPED FROM VOTING

Thousands of people who want to vote could be disenfranchised if the General Election is called before February 15th.

The new electoral register only comes into force after February 15th.

So if any young person applied to be registered late last year, they could be denied a vote.

Or if someone who was angered by the health service decided to recently register, they would be denied a vote.

The only way a potential voter could overcome this would be to apply to be included in a 
supplementary register.

However this requires going to a Garda station and getting a form stamped. They would only have a short period of time to do this.

Fine Gael have been talking about updating the electoral register for some time.

Their main proposal was to insist that voters be required to bring a PPS number to the polling booths.

Many civil society groups, however, proposed that online registration should be introduced so that it would be easier to vote.

If Varadkar wanted to facilitate new voters, he could put the election back a few days or else bring in emergency legislation to allow them to vote.

Let’s see what he does.
Break the cycle of Fine Gael & Fianna Fáil - help elect a real fighter in Dublin Mid West!

ELECTION IS NOT A VARADKAR VERSUS MARTIN SHOW

Fianna Fail and Fine Gael have ruled this country for nearly eighty years and they are trying to narrow this election to a choice between them. But their policies are almost exactly the same.

Today, Fine Gael presides over a health system that has the longest waiting lists in Europe – but when they were n office Fianna Fail cut 2,000 beds from the health service.

Both oppose proper rent controls and regulation of the price of building land because they are devotees of the ‘free market’.

The days of two and a half party system are over. Today both FF and FG command just over half the votes of the electorate whereas in the past they 
had over 80 percent.

People Before Profit is standing in this election to offer a real alternative.

Our aim is to make a start on breaking the cycle of FF and FG rule. We give one cast iron guarantee – a vote for People Before Profit will never be used to put one of the conservative parties into power.

We are advocating policies that promote greater equality, radical climate action and high quality public services. We want to shift the tax burden from PAYE worker and place it more firmly on the shoulders of the wealthy and the big corporations by closing off their tax loopholes.

Google, for example has just declared €15 billion in tax – and has not paid us a penny. Apple owe us €13 billion in back taxes – but the two conservative parties are spending millions of OUR money to ensure we don’t get it.

People Before Profit would put an immediately embargo on the sell-off of public land – and use it for social and affordable houses.
We will bring in a law for proper rent controls that will allow for rent reduction in some cases.

We will massively increase the bus fleet and move to free public transport to tackle climate change.
We can continue the change – but first let’s break the cycle of FF and FG rule.

Solidarity TD Mick Barry this morning said that a new report from the Central Bank shows that the insurance industry have been engaged in “massive profiteering” on motor insurance and that the industry has conducted a “sustained campaign of misinformation” about increased claims and spiralling payouts.
The report shows that over a 10 year period (2009-18) that motor insurance claims went down 2.5% while insurance premiums rose 42%. The average claim per policy was down from €437 to €426 while the average premium rose from €498 to €706.
Meanwhile, average profits rose 9% last year which was nearly double the profits recorded by the industry in the UK.
The reports’ findings fly completely in the face of the industry narrative of increased claims, spiralling costs and pressure on profits.
Deputy Barry said this morning: “The industry has clearly engaged in a sustained campaign of misinformation - claims are down, costs are down and profits are way, way up. While the industry has been putting on poor mouth they have actually been involved in profiteering on a massive scale.  Insurance in this country needs to be completely reorganized and run on a not for profit basis.  The State should establish its own insurance company, take the companies which have ripped off the Irish people into public ownership, and offer insurance for people’s needs not shareholder profit.”

Out on the pickets today!

SUPPORT THE SCHOOL SECRETARIES

Thousands school secretaries will take strike action today. They are protesting over a measly pay offer and to demand job security.

Most school secretaries are employed directly by their school’s board of management and paid from the school’s ancillary grant.

This system shows exactly how school secretaries are undervalued. An ‘ancillary grant’ means that they are paid of the ‘extra bit’ that is left over after other running costs of a school are covered.

In practice, school secretaries are paid a salary of €12,000 a year. One of the main reasons for this is that they receive no pay during holiday periods.

Yet the reality is that there is much administrative work still to be done during holiday times and there is no reason why the jobs should not be a proper year-long post.

Two factors, however, lie behind this strange position.

First, Ireland operates a system whereby religious groups run most of the schools and these receive grants from the state to fun their operations.

Second, the position of schools secretaries is normally held by women. As part of a wider culture of sexism, their pay was seen as just a ‘supplement’ rather than being a proper full time job.

Just as Irish women have stood up in other areas against a disgraceful treatment, school secretaries have moved into action to gain proper respect and pay.

People Before Profit fully supports the school secretaries. It is a disgrace that the Workplace Relations Commission awarded them a ting 1.5% increase.

They deserve far more.

They should be put on the payroll of the Department of Education and given proper job security. It is our hope that the teachers unions will come out fully in support of their colleagues.

Interested in RISE? Here's what we stand for;

https://www.letusrise.ie/what-we-stand-for

After a year-long debate within the Socialist Party, we have decided to leave and to establish a new democratic socialist political group, RISE. The four letters of RISE give a picture of the politics we stand for: Radical, Internationalist, Socialist and Environmentalist.

All around the world, radical young people and workers are on the move. Ten days ago we saw millions of school students in over 150 countries, joined by workers and other young people, participate in the Global Climate Strike, the largest environmental protest in history. This past Friday, millions more young people and workers marched again. This environmental movement joins the global feminist wave as a social movement mobilising millions. Socialist ideas are becoming popularised, seen for example in the 55,000 overwhelmingly new members of the Democratic Socialists of America. If the coming global recession brings the usual calls for cutbacks and wage cuts, it will be met by the resistance of workers internationally.

The question for socialists in Ireland and around the world is how to participate to help build these movements while also advocating for the necessary eco-socialist change. We have been involved as activists in the movements to defeat the water charges, for abortion rights and for the right to housing, to halt climate change and environmental destruction, and many other issues. The conclusion we have drawn is that socialists need to participate in these movements in an open, non-sectarian way, willing to work alongside others who don’t share all of our views, while putting forward our own ideas. In our view this is an important part of socialists contributing to the rebuilding of the broader workers’ movement, including active trade union and housing movements and a new broad mass party of the left.

Our members have joined and are helping to build Extinction Rebellion. We will work alongside hundreds of other activists for the most effective ‘Rebellion Week’ of civil disobedience in October as part of building the mass movement necessary to stop climate change.

One of our key priorities as a group will be to prepare and launch a Green New Deal with socialist policies for Ireland. At this moment of ecological, social and economic crises, a transformative plan is needed - for free, green and frequent public transport, for a rapid and just transition to green energy, including a green jobs programme in renewable energy and care work, for a sustainable model of agriculture that supports our small farmers, for quality low carbon de-commodified public housing, a 4 day week, and a planned economy under the democratic control of working class people. 

We recognise that division amongst the left can be demoralising for working class people who rightly want to see maximum unity against the right wing parties and their policies. Although no longer a part of the Socialist Party, we are committed to co-operating with the Socialist Party and others on the left on a day-to-day basis and will remain part of the Solidarity - People Before Profit grouping.

We will be building RISE as a radical socialist organisation and producing a regular political magazine and website with analysis and commentary (www.letusrise.ie). We also want to contribute to the building of a broader mass party of the left, with a vibrant democratic culture of debate and discussion. This is desperately needed to challenge and end neo-liberal and capitalist domination, which, with its drive to privatise and cut back, has prioritised the needs of big business and the market over our lives and our future.

Patients die because of trolley crisis

The hospital trolley crisis has hit record levels with 760 patients affected.

But an e mail sent by Dr Brendan McCann, the head of the emergency department at University Hospital Waterford, to the HSE has warned of horrific consequences.

Dr McCann pointed out that research in Britain showed that 1 in 83 patents die as a result of waiting over 6 hours in emergency departments.

He wrote that ‘At UHW, this is about two a week or more than 100 a year. I would also point out that our waits are longer than six hours so the figure is likely to be higher.”

Yet this is only one hospital and if we move on to the national figures, we are talking about an estimated 8 people a day possibly dying as a result of the hospital crisis.

The figure could be higher because patients are waiting for longer than 6 hours in many hospitals.

Health Minister, Simon Harris, should stop his PR games and declare a national health emergency.

An immediate campaign must be started to raise the salaries of nurses and doctors so that hospital wards can be staff. Private hospitals should be brought into public ownership and integrated into the health service. Serious measures must be taken to save lives.

Green Fingal Councillor Joe O'Brien says the new runway at Dublin airport will leave as many as 5,000 additional households in north county Dublin impacted by noise, to the detriment of the health and wellbeing of up to 15,000 residents.

"New 'noise zone' maps recently published by Fingal County Council show that noise from the flight pathway of the new runway will have a very significant impact for residents of south Swords, most of Malahide and now all of Portmarnock," says Cllr. O'Brien. "All these areas are in a zone where noise levels are expected to have a negative impact on health, especially for more vulnerable people such a the very young and our older community members."

"Fingal County Council would require noise insulation in a planning application for a new home in these areas once the second runway is opened. However crucially for residents already living in this zone, there is no noise insulation scheme to offset the negative impacts the new runway will have on their quality of life and their health."

"The importance of public health in Fingal is being relegated and ignored in the process of trying to make the airport bigger."

The decision of Charlie Flanagan to commemorate the Royal Irish Constabulary and by extension, the Black and Tans is an outrage. But behind it lies Fine Gael’s ambition to draw this country ever closer into a web of imperialist relations.

The RIC was one of the first police forces ever formed in the world. Their purpose was to keep Ireland safe for the British empire. They were recruited from rural areas and were chosen because they were amongst the biggest and largest men. In 1913, the Dublin Metropolitan Police – the RIC’s counterpart in the city – baton-charged striking workers so ferociously that they murdered two people.

After 1919 a popular struggle – involving thousands of people who took up arms – drove out the RIC and formed liberated zones in parts of the country. Police stations were burnt to the ground and a mass boycott meant that people refused to supply them. The IRA embarked on a campaign of shootings to force them out, killing many RIC officers. By 1920, the RIC had retreated from 500 barracks.

In response to this, Winston Churchill sent in the ‘Black and Tans’ to bolster the RIC. These became part of the official RIC and their name comes from the fact that they combined the Khaki of the British army with the Black of the RIC uniform. Their main tactic was to launch reprisal and murder squads against the population. The activities of the RIC and the Black and Tans are well known in Ireland. They burnt towns like Balbriggan and Cork and murdered innocent people.

Instead of commemorating this brutal, repressive force, we should be celebrating an Irish revolution that drove them out.

But that is not in Fine Gael’s nature. The party has always wanted to bring Ireland back into the Commonwealth and turn us into a minor player in the Anglo-American imperial enterprise.

We should totally reject Flanagan’s stupid idea. But while doing so, let’s link our anger to the contemporary world and demand that the US army also get out of Shannon. If it was right to throw out the Black and Tans, then it is equally right to throw the US and British armies out of Iraq.

USA: hands off Iran!

The US has interfered in Iran for decades - they overthrew a democratically elected government.

They installed the ruthless Shah of Iran. They backed the Iraqi war effort against Iran.

The US empire later destroyed Iraq killing tens of thousands of people.

Trump has thrown petrol on the long burning fires of the Middle East. He wants to distract from his criminal regime and get reelected.

He doesn't care how many have to die.

We say no war on Iran. US military out of Shannon.

The killing of Iranian General Soleimani in Baghdad risks pulling the US closer to a war with Iran.

Such an event would obviously have massive repercussions for ordinary people in the region--many will be slaughtered in Trump's chest beating and war mongering.

Iran has promised that "harsh retaliation is waiting", no doubt the exact response that Trump wanted. 

In part, this attack is motivated by the fact that Trump is seeking to get re-elected in 2020.

However it would be a mistake to think that there is a huge appetite for a war across the whole of the U. S. 

We also cannot forget or forgive the media outlets, politicians and members of the U.S. establishment who have been licking their lips at the prospect of war with Iran for decades now. 

In Belfast, Dublin, Cork all across Ireland we must do all we can to ensure that another war isn't launched on people in the Middle East.

No war on Iran, US military out of Shannon.
